content.question:
In a neutral stable atmosphere, the Environmental Lapse Rate (ELR) in the case of unsaturated air equals (1)_____, and ELR in the case of saturated air equals (2)_____.
DALR Dry Adiabatic Lapse Rate
SALR Saturated Adiabatic Lapse Rate

key_points: The temperature change of an air parcel depends on its saturation state
When rising air is unsaturated, it follows the dry adiabatic lapse rate
This leads to three possible scenarios: If the environmental lapse rate (ELR) is lower than the dry adiabatic lapse rate (DALR), the atmosphere is considered stable (DALR > ELR)
learning.explanation: The temperature change of an air parcel depends on its saturation state. When rising air is unsaturated, it follows the dry adiabatic lapse rate. This leads to three possible scenarios: If the environmental lapse rate (ELR) is lower than the dry adiabatic lapse rate (DALR), the atmosphere is considered stable (DALR > ELR). If the environmental lapse rate (ELR) is higher than the dry adiabatic lapse rate(DALR), the atmosphere is deemed unstable (DALR < ELR). If the environmental lapse rate (ELR) is equal to the dry adiabatic lapse rate (DALR), the equilibrium is classified as neutral (DALR = ELR). On the other hand, when the rising air parcel is saturated, its temperature change adheres to the saturated adiabatic lapse rate. This also yields three possibilities: If the environmental lapse rate (ELR) is lower than the saturated adiabatic lapse rate (SALR), the atmosphere is stable (SALR > ELR). If the environmental lapse rate (ELR) is higher than the saturated adiabatic lapse rate (SALR), the atmosphere is unstable (SALR < ELR). If the environmental lapse rate is equal to the saturated adiabatic lapse rate, the equilibrium is neutral (SALR = ELR).

content.question:
Which of the following statements are correct/incorrect?
1. The actual temperature of an air mass is higher than the dew point temperature if the air mass is unsaturated.
2. For a saturated air mass, the dew point temperature over ice is lower than the dew point temperature over water.

key_points: “The actual temperature of an air mass is higher than the dew point temperature if the air mass is unsaturated
" CORRECT Dew point (DP) is the temperature to which air must be cooled at constant pressure for saturation to occur
When the dew point temperature and air temperature are equal, the air is said to be saturated (relative humidity = 100%)
learning.explanation: “The actual temperature of an air mass is higher than the dew point temperature if the air mass is unsaturated." CORRECT Dew point (DP) is the temperature to which air must be cooled at constant pressure for saturation to occur. When the dew point temperature and air temperature are equal, the air is said to be saturated (relative humidity = 100%). Dew point temperature can never be greater than the air temperature. Therefore, if the air cools below the original dew point, moisture must be removed from the air and this is accomplished through condensation. Summary: • for unsaturated air – dew point is lower than air temperature; and • for saturated air – dew point is equal to air temperature. "For a saturated air mass, the dew point temperature over ice is lower than the dew point temperature over water." INCORRECT This one is a bit more complicated, but in simple terms, if the air temperature is below the freezing point of water (0ºC) and therefore ice crystals can be formed instead of water droplets, then the air will favour the formation of ice. Due to the saturation vapour pressure over ice being lower than water, the amount of water vapour that can be held before forming ice crystals is LESS than can be held before forming water droplets. This means that ice crystals are formed earlier than water droplets, so ice has a HIGHER temperature frost point than water's dew point. (They have referred to "dew point temperature over ice" which is the same as "frost point").

content.question: The decrease in temperature, per 100 meters, in a saturated rising parcel of air at lower level of the atmosphere is approximately:

key_points: The temperature lapse rate of air is the amount of temperature change the air experiences over a difference in height
There are a different lapse rates, depending on the situation

This question is simply asking about the SALR (Saturated Adiabatic Lapse Rate) DALR (Dry Adiabatic Lapse Rate) - This is the amount of temperature that dry (non-saturated) air changes by if it rises or sinks in the atmosphere
learning.explanation: The temperature lapse rate of air is the amount of temperature change the air experiences over a difference in height. There are a different lapse rates, depending on the situation. This question is simply asking about the SALR (Saturated Adiabatic Lapse Rate) DALR (Dry Adiabatic Lapse Rate) - This is the amount of temperature that dry (non-saturated) air changes by if it rises or sinks in the atmosphere. Adiabatic means that no external temperatures affect it, and any parcel of dry air will conform to this DALR if moved up or down. The DALR is -3ºC/1000ft, meaning that for every 1 000 ft gained, a dry parcel of air will reduce in temperature by 3ºC. This happens because air rises into lower pressure, therefore expanding and making the molecules further apart, so less collisions occur and less heat is present. SALR (Saturated Adiabatic Lapse Rate) - This is the same concept as for the DALR, but has an added layer of complication. When saturated (Relative Humidity 100%) air rises, it will become cooler (as is standard due to expansion), but that means that the air can no longer hold as much water, so some water is released as condensation, turning into liquid water droplets. This process is going from a high energy state (water vapour) to a lower energy state (liquid), meaning that latent heat is released (see annex above). The release of latent heat adds temperature to the air, which gains back a little of the 3ºC lost per 1 000 ft (DALR). This means that saturated air does not lose heat as quickly with altitude as dry air does, but by how much depends on the heat of the air (and therefore the water content. More water to condense means that more energy is put into the atmosphere, so the air cools less, so the wetter air cools slower with altitude increase). For standard temperatures we say that the SALR is about -1.8ºC/1000ft, meaning that the water condensation releases 1.8ºC into the atmosphere every 1 000 ft. Sometimes lapse rates are measured in degrees (ºC) per 100 m, in which case, the DALR would be -1ºC/100m and the SALR would be -0.6ºC/100m on average (remember, the SALR can change). ELR (Environmental Lapse Rate) - This is the ACTUAL change in temperature throughout the atmosphere, measured by a radiosonde. The ELR decides whether pockets of air that moves upwards or downwards will be unstable or stable, as the ELR dictates what the moving air will have to compare its temperature to (read up on stability for more explanation).

learning.explanation: The formation of clouds and precipitation can be simplified into a simple recipe: water and dust. Clouds are composed primarily of water in its liquid and solid state. Thus, we begin our recipe by collecting sufficient water vapour - that we will soon transform into the liquid or solid states. The water vapor content of the atmosphere varies from near zero to about 5 percent, depending on the moisture on the surface beneath and the air temperature. Next, we need some dust (Micrometric solid particles). Without "dirty air" there would likely be no clouds at all or only high altitude ice clouds. Even the "cleanest" air found on Earth contains about 1000 dust particles per cubic meter of air. Dust is needed for condensation nuclei, sites on which water vapor may condense or deposit as a liquid or solid. Without a nuclei for water to condense onto, air has been known to become “supersaturated” with water in lab conditions, up to 400% of the usual maximum humidity. With proper quantities of water vapor and dust in an air parcel, the next step is for the air parcel mass to be cooled to a temperature at which cloud droplets or ice crystals can form (dew point).

Stability of the atmosphere can be defined using the relationship of ELR (Environmental Lapse Rate), DALR (Dry Adiabatic Lapse Rate) and SALR (Saturated Adiabatic Lapse Rate): Absolute stability: ELR is less than SALR => ELR is less than 1.8°C per 1 000 ft (0.6°C per 100 m). Relationship is: ELR < SALR < DALR. Absolute instability: ELR is greater than DALR => ELR is greater than 3°C per 1 000 ft (1°C per 100 m). Relationship is: SALR < DALR < ELR. Conditional instability: ELR is between 1.8°C and 3°C per 1 000 ft. Relationship is: SALR < ELR < DALR. Because in an isothermal layer the temperature does not change with altitude, the ELR is 0 and thus less than the SALR. That is why an isothermal layer is absolutely stable.

Depends on moisture content and the temperature of the air. RH = (HMR/SMR) x 100 RH 100% = Saturation Now, let’s talk about Relative Humidity in more detail. As we have discussed above, RH depends on moisture content and temperature. In simple words, it is given as a percentage and tells you how close the air is to being saturated. Consequently, if the relative humidity is 100%, the air is saturated. If the relative humidity is 50%, the air contains half the water vapor required for it to be saturated. As air temperature increases, air can hold more water molecules, therefore, if the water vapor content stays the same and the temperature increases, the relative humidity decreases. On the other hand, since colder air doesn’t require as much moisture to become saturated as warmer air, if temperature drops, relative humidity increases. content.question:
Refer to figure.
Which of the following atmospheric conditions would reduce or prevent turbulence in that area?

options.A: Atmospheric stability, with an Environmental Lapse Rate (ELR) greater than the Saturated Adiabatic Lapse Rate (SALR).
options.B: Atmospheric instability, with an Environmental Lapse Rate (ELR) greater than the Dry Adiabatic Lapse Rate (DALR).
options.C: Atmospheric instability, with an Environmental Lapse Rate (ELR) less than the Dry Adiabatic Lapse Rate (DALR).
options.D: Atmospheric stability, with an Environmental Lapse Rate (ELR) less than the Saturated Adiabatic Lapse Rate (SALR).

key_points: A very large factor in the formation of turbulence is the atmospheric stability
In essence, stability is the measurement of how air reacts to being forced upwards
If air is forced to rise by some force, once the force disappears, stable air will begin to sink back to the original altitude, and unstable air will continue to rise
learning.explanation: A very large factor in the formation of turbulence is the atmospheric stability. In essence, stability is the measurement of how air reacts to being forced upwards. If air is forced to rise by some force, once the force disappears, stable air will begin to sink back to the original altitude, and unstable air will continue to rise. This is all to do with the temperature of the different layers of atmosphere, called the Environmental Lapse Rate (ELR). If there is a high ELR, then the atmosphere drops in temperature with altitude quite rapidly. If there is a low ELR, it means that the temperature does not drop as quickly with altitude, and even an ELR of 0 (an isothermal layer) or an increase of temperature with altitude (an inversion) can also occur. The air which is forced to rise will not change temperature at the ELR though, it changes temperature with the DALR (Dry Adiabatic Lapse Rate = 3ºC/1000ft) when unsaturated, or the SALR (Saturated Adiabatic Lapse Rate [variable, usually around 1.8ºC/1000ft; always less than the DALR]) when fully saturated with water vapour. If this makes the air parcel warmer than the surrounding atmosphere, then the atmosphere is unstable, and will rise, and the opposite for if it becomes cooler than the atmosphere. This creates 3 regions of stability: Absolute stability, when the ELR is less than the SALR. Conditional stability, when the ELR is between the SALR and the DALR. (saturated air is unstable but dry air is stable in this atmosphere) Absolute instability, when the ELR is greater than the DALR. A good way to remember which way round these are is that isothermal layers and inversions are always absolutely stable, and act like an air blockade. Stability causes less uplift in the atmosphere, allowing for smoother flying conditions with less turbulence which is when the ELR is less than the SALR. content.question: The presence of altocumulus lenticularis is an indication of the..

key_points: Learning Objective 050
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 050.02.05.01.04: Explain how mountain waves may be identified by their associated meteorological phenomena. Having fast airflow over a mountain causes a lot of vertical movement of air, with large updrafts on the windward side of the mountain as the air climbs, as well as large downdrafts on the lee side where the air descends back to the surface. These "mountain waves" often continue downwind of the high ground similar to waves on the ocean, and can have this up and down "wave" motion for hundreds of miles in some cases. The downdrafts within these waves can be so powerful that lower performance aircraft may not be able to climb at all when within one. Mountain waves (or standing waves) are therefore very dangerous to aircraft, and if the right conditions exist, mountain waves can continue as high as the tropopause in some cases. There are some tell-tale signs of mountain waves though. Lenticular clouds (cloud type lenticularis) are clouds which are shaped like a lens, and they stay in the same location, even though the wind in their location is strong. They are indicative of the presence of mountain waves, and look very smooth, but actually contain lots of windshear and turbulence nearby and within them. Wind rotors exist in the region of lenticular clouds, and sometimes have associated roll/rotor clouds, which are also indicative of severe turbulence.

content.question: A strong inversion in the middle section of the troposphere would _____ the vertical development of a Cumulonimbus cloud.

key_points: Note: We have incomplete feedback about this question, and particularly the options available
Please send us any further feedback you can remember from the real exam via the comments, your dashboard, or by email to info@atplquestions
com, so we can verify and improve the question, thank you! A Cumulonimbus cloud (CB) is the type that forms storms
learning.explanation: Note: We have incomplete feedback about this question, and particularly the options available. Please send us any further feedback you can remember from the real exam via the comments, your dashboard, or by email to info@atplquestions.com, so we can verify and improve the question, thank you! A Cumulonimbus cloud (CB) is the type that forms storms. For a CB to form, there must be three things; instability, moisture, and a trigger (something which forces air to rise). When the cloud forms and the air is rising in an unstable air mass, the rising air does not cool down at the same rate as the surrounding environment, and this is what we call instability. This means that the rising air wants to continue rising with more and more velocity. When instability and moisture are great enough, these clouds can form large CBs, which continue to accelerate as long as instability exists. If the air becomes more stable, then the cloud's development will slow down (as it no longer has as much of a temperature difference with the surrounding air. This is most commonly seen at the tropopause, where the surrounding air temperature stops changing (an isothermal layer), and all CBs are stopped at the tropopause, flowing outwards to form an "anvil" shape (sometimes overshooting with a small "hat" from the excess velocity). Isothermal layers are inherently very stable, as the rising air cools as it rises, so will never be the same temperature as air which remains the same temperature. This means that inversions are even more stable. Stability is based on the environmental lapse rate (ELR - the rate at which the surrounding air cools with temperature) vs the Dry or Wet Adiabatic Lapse Rate (DALR or SALR) of the rising parcel of air. The DALR is constant and the SALR is close to constant, but the ELR varies massively. The greater the ELR (greater temperature drop per 1000 ft), the less stable the atmosphere. When the ELR is 0 (isothermal layer), or an inversion occurs, the air is absolutely stable. A strong inversion in the mid layers of the troposphere (so 10 - 20,000 ft) would stop a CB's development very quickly indeed. All of a sudden, the rising air in the CB would not be warmer than the surrounding air, and would stop or sink instead of rising. The cloud would have no further development above this point.

key_points: STEAM FOG (ARCTIC SEA SMOKE)
occurs over sea, mainly in polar regions
It is caused when low-level cold air from a land mass moves over a (comparatively) warmer sea (water surface) = advection of very cold air over a warm sea
learning.explanation: STEAM FOG (ARCTIC SEA SMOKE). occurs over sea, mainly in polar regions. It is caused when low-level cold air from a land mass moves over a (comparatively) warmer sea (water surface) = advection of very cold air over a warm sea. The small amount of evaporation from the sea in the cold air just above it is enough to cause saturation and condensation. Steam fog is typically up to 500 feet thick and may drift inland. It forms in conditions of no wind or very light winds. It will be dispersed by an increase/decrease in wind speed or change of direction. It will also be dispersed if the water becomes colder or the air becomes warmer (the temperature difference reduces). To look at each option: "Radiation cooling and the creation of a ground inversion." This means that the low-level air is getting colder, which would not dissipate the sea smoke. "Inflow of warm air at higher levels, reducing relative humidity." High level changes do not affect sea smoke formation/dissipation. It is a low-level phenomenon only. "Inflow of unstable air, dissipating any surface inversion." This is correct. Unstable air without a surface inversion will be warmer near the surface, so the sea smoke will dissipate as the air temperature rises above the dewpoint.

It begins when the Earth's surface is heated by the sun, warming the air just above it

learning.explanation: Cumulus clouds form primarily through the process of convection. It begins when the Earth's surface is heated by the sun, warming the air just above it. Warm air is lighter and less dense than cool air, so it begins to rise. As the warm air rises, it cools adiabatically (without gaining or losing heat), and when it reaches its dew point temperature (the temperature at which air becomes saturated with moisture), water vapor starts to condense into tiny water droplets. These droplets cluster together to form visible cumulus clouds. These clouds can grow rapidly, when the atmosphere is unstable, with no upper-air inversion, and may develop into cumulonimbus clouds, with their tops reaching the tropopause. The vertical extent of cumulus clouds is limited by the stability of the atmosphere. If the atmosphere is stable, meaning that the temperature increases with height (inversion). A subsidence inversion occurs when there is a layer of sinking or subsiding air in the atmosphere. This sinking air warms adiabatically (without heat exchange) as it descends, causing a temperature increase with height. This warm layer acts as a lid or cap on the rising warm air, preventing it from ascending further.

content.question: Fog or mist will start to form when the air becomes saturated, this may happen when: Temperature (1) _____ to the dew point temperature and/or there is (2) _____ in dew point temperature to that of the air temperature.

key_points: Dew, fog or clouds form when the invisible water vapour in the air condenses into liquid water

learning.explanation: Dew, fog or clouds form when the invisible water vapour in the air condenses into liquid water. For this to happen, the parcel of air must be saturated (Relative Humidity = 100%) - which means that the air parcel is unable to hold all the water it contains in vapour form, so it starts to condense. There are two ways by which saturation is reached: (a) By increasing the water content in the air. I.e. through evaporation, to a point where the air can hold no more. (b) By cooling the air so that it reaches its dew point - this is the temperature at which condensation occurs, and is unable to "hold" any more water. The dew point is always lower than (or equal to) the air temperature => If the air temperature cools to the dew point, or if the dew point rises to equal the air temperature, then water vapour condenses and dew, fog or clouds begin to form. At this point where the dew point temperature equals the air temperature, the relative humidity is 100%. For condensation to occur, temperature must equal dew point.

learning.explanation: To have a rough idea on the Cloud Base height, we can refer to the following formula: (Air temperature at surface – dew point temperature) x 400 A general rule of thumb is that the wider the gap between the temperature and dew point, the higher the cloud base is likely to be. When temperature rises during the day, dew point spread will increase and cloud base will be higher. When Relative Humidity is low, you would expect a HIGH cloud base. On the other hand, a lower difference between temperature and dew point (and, consequently, High Relative Humidity), leads to a LOWer cloud base. To calculate cloud tops, we need to know the SALR and ELR => cloud tops are located where SALR meets ELR. Why? Because air in clouds is rising with SALR - air is saturated (moist). Saturated air cools down slower and as long as enough moisture is available the cloud will keep growing. When SALR = ELR (temperature of air parcel in cloud = temperature of environment) the parcel of air cannot ascend (rise) any more because there is no difference in temperature (no difference in density). Hence, top of clouds is defined.

content.question: "Frontal fog" may occur when low cloud covers the surface with the passage of a front, more commonly over hills than over low ground. It may also develop when...

options.A: dust particles blown by strong winds at a cold front become condensation nuclei for water droplets.
options.B: the air becomes saturated by continuous rain falling from warm air above a frontal surface.
options.C: cold air crossing warm, damp ground absorbs water vapour, which then recondenses in the cold air.
options.D: a cold front cools the warm air it displaces, at the surface, to below its dew point.

key_points: Learning Objective 050
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 050.04.02.05.01: Explain the formation of frontal fog. Frontal fog is a term that can be used to describe any fog that was caused by frontal activity, so includes the "hill fog" mentioned in the question, which is actually just cloud that is low enough to touch the high ground. The more common definition of frontal fog is a special type of fog that only happens under a warm front, just before it passes. Before a warm front passes, we are in a cold sector, so the air is cold, and therefore the ground is relatively cold as well. There is, however, warmer rain falling from above, at least towards the latter stages of the front passing. This is warm rain falling through cold air, and tends to bring a high amount of humidity to the air it goes through. This humidity is most when the warm rain hits the cold ground and begins to evaporate. At this point, we have a lot of humidity in cold air, which leads to the air becoming quickly saturated, and frontal fog is formed. Sometimes this is complemented by stratus fractus, which are small patches of stratus cloud that hang in the air.

content.question: Which type of inversion can lead to fog formation due to the temperature of air in contact with the surface dropping below its dew point when it contacts a colder surface?

key_points: An inversion in the atmosphere is where temperature rises with an increase in height
This produces extreme stability There are four kinds of inversions: ground, turbulence, subsidence, and frontal

GROUND INVERSION - develops when air is cooled by contact with a colder surface until it becomes cooler than the overlying atmosphere; this occurs most often on clear nights, when the ground cools off rapidly by radiation
learning.explanation: An inversion in the atmosphere is where temperature rises with an increase in height. This produces extreme stability There are four kinds of inversions: ground, turbulence, subsidence, and frontal. GROUND INVERSION - develops when air is cooled by contact with a colder surface until it becomes cooler than the overlying atmosphere; this occurs most often on clear nights, when the ground cools off rapidly by radiation. If the temperature of surface air drops below its dew point, fog may result. TURBULENCE INVERSION - often forms when quiescent air overlies turbulent air. Within the turbulent layer, vertical mixing carries heat downward and cools the upper part of the layer. The unmixed air above is not cooled and eventually is warmer than the air below; an inversion then exists. SUBSIDENCE INVERSION - develops when a widespread layer of air descends. The layer is compressed and heated by the resulting increase in atmospheric pressure, and, as a result, the lapse rate of temperature is reduced. If the air mass sinks low enough, the air at higher altitudes becomes warmer than at lower altitudes, producing a temperature inversion. FRONTAL INVERSION - occurs when a cold air mass undercuts a warm air mass and lifts it aloft; the front between the two air masses then has warm air above and cold air below.

Surface - only occurs over land, because ground surface is a better heat conductor than sea surface.

key_points: Cumulus clouds are formed through the process of convection
Convection involves the vertical movement of air masses, particularly the rising of warm air
The trigger for the formation of cumulus clouds is heating from below
learning.explanation: Cumulus clouds are formed through the process of convection. Convection involves the vertical movement of air masses, particularly the rising of warm air. The trigger for the formation of cumulus clouds is heating from below. This heating can occur due to the warming of the Earth's surface by sunlight. As the surface heats up, it warms the air above it. When this warm air rises, it cools and condenses to form cumulus clouds. The vertical growth of cumulus clouds is restricted by a subsidence inversion. A subsidence inversion occurs when descending air in the atmosphere creates a layer of warmer air above cooler air. This layer acts as a barrier to vertical air movement, preventing further upward growth of the cumulus cloud. It inhibits the vertical development of the cloud, leading to the characteristic flattened appearance of cumulus clouds.

key_points: CUMULUS HUMILIS, often referred to as "fair weather cumulus", are cumuliform clouds with little vertical extent, common in the summer - formed by local heating of the surface, even in a stable atmosphere
They are fairly distinct and easy to classify in relation to other clouds: they’re a cumulus cloud that’s wider than tall
They’re flattened cumulus and are generally found low in altitude
learning.explanation: CUMULUS HUMILIS, often referred to as "fair weather cumulus", are cumuliform clouds with little vertical extent, common in the summer - formed by local heating of the surface, even in a stable atmosphere. They are fairly distinct and easy to classify in relation to other clouds: they’re a cumulus cloud that’s wider than tall. They’re flattened cumulus and are generally found low in altitude. Its vertical growth is usually restricted by the existence of a temperature inversion in the atmosphere - cooling of the surface stops convection and increases stability in the airmass which causes clouds to dissipate. Within the cloud, ascending currents of about 2–5 m/s (7–17 ft/s) may be encountered. Turbulence is sometimes severe, especially during the formation and growth of the cloud, and it diminishes when the cloud is mature. Air below the cloud base can be quite turbulent due to the thermals that formed the clouds, giving occupants of light aircraft an uncomfortable ride. To avoid turbulence where such clouds are present, pilots may climb above the cloud tops.

learning.explanation: Learning Objective 050.04.02.04.01: Explain the formation of sea smoke. STEAM FOG (ARCTIC SEA SMOKE). occurs over sea, mainly in polar regions. It is caused when cold air (usually from a land mass) moves over a (comparatively) warmer sea = advection of very cold air over warm water. The small amount of evaporation from the sea is enough to cause saturation and condensation in the air close to the surface. A surface inversion has to be in place (and is usually because of cooling from the cold land mass) so this sea smoke does not continue rising into clouds. Steam fog is typically up to 500 feet thick and may drift inland. Forms in conditions of no wind or very light winds. Will be dispersed by an increase/decrease in wind speed or certain change of wind direction. Whereas clouds and fog are usually formed due to cooling of air, this is a case of fog being formed by increasing the humidity of the air. The best way to remember sea smoke is to think of a hot tub in a very cold climate, it forms "steam fog" in the same way that sea smoke occurs, just with a bigger temperature difference.

key_points: In an unstable air mass, cumulus clouds will often form during the day, particularly due to surface heating, causing localised thermal uplift and then convection due to the instability of the air mass

When the Sun becomes lower in the sky in an evening, the solar heating on the ground decreases, which reduces thermal uplift, as well as reducing low level heating of the air mass, which increases the stability of the air mass

learning.explanation: In an unstable air mass, cumulus clouds will often form during the day, particularly due to surface heating, causing localised thermal uplift and then convection due to the instability of the air mass. When the Sun becomes lower in the sky in an evening, the solar heating on the ground decreases, which reduces thermal uplift, as well as reducing low level heating of the air mass, which increases the stability of the air mass. All this reduces the convection of cumulus clouds, and gradually stops them growing any further, or new ones forming. Sometimes, if there have been large CB clouds formed during the late afternoon, they will have enough momentum and energy left in them to continue producing thunderstorms into the late evening and night.

learning.explanation: The METAR information provides details about the current weather conditions. In the given excerpt, "400 R24/0650 FG" indicates the presence of fog ("FG") with a visibility of 400 meters and a runway visual range (RVR) of 650 meters. Additionally, "NSC" indicates that there are no significant clouds. The wind direction is 220º at 5 KT. The temperature and dew point are both reported as 03/03, which indicated high relative humidity. key_points: In the troposphere, inversions cause an increase in stability and tend to limit the upward growth of clouds, preventing further upward convection
Essentially, the vertical development of clouds, determined by humidity and temperature differences between the cloud and the surroundings, is influenced
If the air temperature equals or exceeds the cloud's temperature, cloud growth ceases
learning.explanation: In the troposphere, inversions cause an increase in stability and tend to limit the upward growth of clouds, preventing further upward convection. Essentially, the vertical development of clouds, determined by humidity and temperature differences between the cloud and the surroundings, is influenced. If the air temperature equals or exceeds the cloud's temperature, cloud growth ceases. In simple terms, a temperature inversion is a thin layer of the atmosphere where the normal decrease in temperature with height reverses, leading to temperature increases with height. It acts as a lid, inhibiting the typical convective overturning of the atmosphere from penetrating through the inversion.

learning.explanation: Lenticular clouds (cloud type lenticularis) are clouds which are shaped like a lens, and they stay in the same location, even though the wind in their location is strong. They are indicative of the presence of mountain waves, and look very smooth, but actually contain lots of windshear and turbulence nearby and within them. Wind rotors exist in the region of lenticular clouds, and sometimes have associated roll/rotor clouds, which are also indicative of severe turbulence. "Stratocumulus clouds": stratocumulus clouds are generally stable and not known for causing severe turbulence. "Nimbostratus clouds": Nimbostratus clouds are typically associated with steady, widespread precipitation and often have a layered structure. While these clouds may cause areas of light to moderate turbulence, severe turbulence is less likely as they are generally more stable. "Cirrocumulus clouds": Cirrocumulus clouds are high-altitude clouds composed of small white, fluffy cloudlets. They are usually not associated with severe turbulence as they form at high levels and typically indicate stable atmospheric conditions.

If sufficient moisture is present to condense, the cloud mass could rise through several levels – before it encounters the boundary between the troposphere and the stratosphere – TROPOPAUSE. content.question: The top of a stratus cloud is typically upheld by a capping (1)_____ situated (2)_____ the cloud's top.

learning.explanation: Under normal ISA conditions, warm air ascends until it reaches its condensation point, at which clouds form and the heat released during condensation continues to propel the upward movement of the air. Once all the moisture has condensed, cloud formation ceases. However, the presence of an inversion, often referred to as an isothermal layer, disrupts this upward motion. Inversions occur when the rising air encounters a layer of air that is warmer, causing it to halt its ascent. Consequently, inversions frequently cap clouds and fog layers. Moreover, an inversion inhibits the vertical movement of other atmospheric particles contained within the air pocket. As a result, an area above an inversion layer typically remains clear of clouds, smog, mist, and haze, among other things. In addition, there is an increase in wind speed above the inversion compared to just below it, resulting in significant wind shear at the inversion layer.

content.question: In mid-latitudes, the tops of cumulus are often limited by:

key_points: In the troposphere, inversions cause an increase in stability and tend to limit the upward growth of cloud, preventing further upward convection

Basically, up and down currents within clouds, which lead to their vertical development, are decided by humidity and temperature differences (between the cloud and the surroundings) - if the air temperature is equal or higher than the cloud's temperature, clouds will stop growing
In simple words, a temperature inversion is a thin layer of the atmosphere where the normal decrease in temperature with height switches to the temperature increasing with height
learning.explanation: In the troposphere, inversions cause an increase in stability and tend to limit the upward growth of cloud, preventing further upward convection. Basically, up and down currents within clouds, which lead to their vertical development, are decided by humidity and temperature differences (between the cloud and the surroundings) - if the air temperature is equal or higher than the cloud's temperature, clouds will stop growing. In simple words, a temperature inversion is a thin layer of the atmosphere where the normal decrease in temperature with height switches to the temperature increasing with height. It acts like a lid, keeping normal convective overturning of the atmosphere from penetrating through the inversion. Some of the effects it might have: An inversion might cause clouds just below the inversion to spread out and take on a flattened appearance. Still another effect is to prevent thunderstorms from forming. Even in an air mass that is hot and humid in the lowest layers, thunderstorms will be prevented if an inversion in the lower atmosphere is keeping this air from rising. The conceptual opposite of a temperature inversion is an unstable air layer.

content.question: A mountain range spans from South to North and the wind is 270°/10 kt. Orographic fog is expected:

options.B: On the leeward side of the mountain.
options.C: On the southern part of the mountain.
options.D: On the windward side of the mountain.

key_points: HILL/OROGRAPHIC FOG
Usually stratiform cloud (ST, SC) whose base is lower than the summit of the hills
Formed when humid stable air is forced to ascend along the side of a mountain or hill (windward side of the mountain) or by the normal turbulence action producing ST and SC
learning.explanation: HILL/OROGRAPHIC FOG. Usually stratiform cloud (ST, SC) whose base is lower than the summit of the hills. Formed when humid stable air is forced to ascend along the side of a mountain or hill (windward side of the mountain) or by the normal turbulence action producing ST and SC. Formed during the day or night. As the air rises, it cools adiabatically => condensation level is reached, and a cloud is formed. Hill fog requires a wind up the slopes of a mountain and is promoted by high humidity. The hill fog quickly disappears if the wind changes.

learning.explanation: 1 and 2 – depict CUMULUS cloud. CUMULUS. Classified as heaped cloud, are puffy clouds that sometimes look like pieces of floating cotton. Are detached, individual, cauliflower-shaped clouds usually spotted in fair weather conditions. 6 and 7 – depict ALTOCUMULUS cloud. Altocumulus take the form of speckled white or grey clouds. The patches of cloud appear as rounded masses of fibrous or diﬀuse aspect. There are two forms of altocumulus which are of significance: ALTOCUMULUS CASTELLANUS (6) – characterised by the presence of “towers” that are like battlements on castles. ALTOCUMULUS LENTICULARIS (7) - appear as lens-shaped patches of Altocumulus.
